key_points: Vice President Kamala Harris will address United Nations members about preparing for future pandemics.
The speech is virtual and marks Harris' second to a U.N. body since her inauguration.
Her address emphasizes the need for global leaders to start working on pandemic response plans.
The address comes as the U.S. progresses in vaccinating its population and other countries face vaccine shortages.
Harris' speech is co-hosted by the U.N. permanent representatives of Argentina, Japan, Norway, and South Africa.
The Biden administration is nearing its first 100 days, with President Joe Biden set to highlight pandemic response accomplishments in a forthcoming Congress address.
Harris will outline key focus areas like improving health system accessibility, investing in science and health workers, and increasing manufacturing capacity for protective equipment and vaccines.
The speech acknowledges lessons learned from the past year's pandemic response efforts, highlighting the need for innovation.
U.N. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield will also speak, urging the creation of a future pandemic preparedness architecture.
"The world barely withstood this pandemic," Thomas-Greenfield says, underscoring the importance of readiness for future health crises.
spokespersons: Kamala Harris (Vice President of the United States)
Linda Thomas-Greenfield (U.S. Ambassador to the U.N.)
